review.title: Recognizability of Individual Creative Style Within and Across Domains: Preliminary Studies
review.abstract: It is hypothesized that creativity arises from the self-mending capacity of an internal model of the world, or worldview. The uniquely honed worldview of a creative individual results in a distinctive style that is recognizable within and across domains. It is further hypothesized that creativity is domaingeneral in the sense that there exist multiple avenues by which the distinctiveness of one's worldview can be expressed. These hypotheses were tested using art students and creative writing students. Art students guessed significantly above chance both which painting was done by which of five famous artists, and which artwork was done by which of their peers. Similarly, creative writing students guessed significantly above chance both which passage was written by which of five famous writers, and which passage was written by which of their peers. These findings support the hypothesis that creative style is recognizable. Moreover, creative writing students guessed significantly above chance which of their peers produced particular works of art, supporting the hypothesis that creative style is recognizable not just within but across domains.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: The therapeutic nature of the creative process is well known. Eminent creators and laymen alike claim that by engaging in creative activities they acquire a clearer sense of themselves as unique individuals. By making artistic decisions and observing how these decisions guide subsequent thoughts about the work, which culminate in an original, creative form, they acquire self-awareness, and often remain a sense of completeness. The transformation that takes place on the canvas or on the written page is supposed to be reflected in a sense of personal transformation and self-discovery that happens without. Artists often find a style that feels as if it is "theirs" only after phases of exploration with various media and established styles and art forms. Likewise, writers speak of the transition from a phase in which they merely imitate the styles of authors they admire to a phase in which they discover their own authentic "voices."

sections.heading: Theories of Creativity
sections.text: This section briefly summarizes some of the leading theories on the workings of the creative process and then introduces a new theory of creativity called the Honor Theory.

sections.heading: Creativity as Heuristic Search
sections.text: Inspired by the metaphor of the mind as a computer (or computer program), it has been suggested that creativity involves a process of heuristic search, in which rules of thumb guide the inspection of various states within a given state space (set of possible solutions) until a satisfactory solution is found (Eysenck, 1993; Newell, Shaw & Simon 1957; Newell & Simon 1972).heuristic search defines the relevant variables from the front; therefore, the state space is generally defined.Examples of heuristics are the division of the problem into partial problems, mountaineering (repeated modification of the current state to look more like the target state) and backward work from the target state to the starting state.One deviation from this view is the view that creativity involves heuristics, which guide the search for not a possibility within a given state space, but for a new state space itself (e.g. soil, 1990; Kaplan & Simon, 1990; Ohlsson, 1992), sometimes called a change from the problem to a mount.

sections.heading: The Expertise View of Creativity
sections.text: Some argue that creativity encompasses everyday thought processes such as remembering, planning, arguing, and restructuring; no specific or unconscious thought processes need to be postulated (Perkins, 1981; Weisberg, 2006). This is sometimes called an expert view of creativity because it emphasizes the extent to which creative actions are based on familiarity with a particular area of knowledge. Thus, this view is particularly associated with the notion that creativity is highly domain-specific; expertise in one domain is not considered an enhancement of creativity in another domain; the expert view is also associated with the notion that the creative process produces products that are largely derivative or reproductive (as Weisberg puts it) and not really new or productive.

sections.heading: The Darwinian Theory of Creativity
sections.text: While some philosophers describe the growth of knowledge as Darwinian only in the sense that presumptions must be refutable, i.e. selectively selectable against them (Popper, 1963; Lorenz, 1971), Campbell (1960) goes further and argues that a stream of creative thinking is a Darwinian process, the basic idea being that we generate new ideas through "blind" variation and selective maintenance (abbreviated to BVSR): "mutation" of contemporary thinking in many ways, selection of the most appropriate variant (s) and repetition of this process until a satisfactory idea emerges; the variants are "blind" in the sense that the creator has no subjective certainty as to whether they are a step towards the final creative product.At present, the Darwinian view of creativity is most closely associated with Simonton (1998, 1999a, b, 2007a, b).

sections.heading: The Honing Theory of Creativity
sections.text: The Honing theory postulates that creativity arises from the self-organizing, self-repairing nature of a world view, and that it sharpens (and resharpens) an integrated world view through the creative process of the individual. Honing theory places the same emphasis on the outwardly visible creative outcome and the internal cognitive restructuring induced by the creative process. Indeed, one factor that sets it apart from other theories of creativity is that it focuses not only on restructuring as it relates to the conception of the task, but also on the search for the outwardly visible creative outcome and the inner cognitive restructuring of the world view as a whole.

sections.heading: The Recognizability of Creative Style
sections.text: There is no reason to expect that the act of creation will lead to a clearer or more integrated self-image, or that the work of a particular creator will be limited in a particular area, especially when it comes to creating a global consciousness.

sections.heading: Style
sections.text: The first study tested the hypothesis that people who are very familiar with the art of a particular artist will recognize other works by that artist that they have not previously encountered.

sections.heading: Method
sections.text: The study was conducted with 10 students from the University of British Columbia who specialized in art that was very familiar with five well-known artists and each other's art. Materials and Procedures Prior to the study, participants were instructed to bring from home a recently completed painting that they had never discussed or exhibited with their classmates, and were asked to hide their signatures or other identifying features of the painting. Prior to the study, the paintings were examined to ensure that signatures and other identifying features were concealed. At the beginning of the study, the art students were shown three well-known paintings by five well-known artists each, the well-known artists being Picasso, Van Gogh, and Andy Warhol. These artists were decided upon the previous discussion with the class that they were very familiar.

sections.heading: Results
sections.text: The results are divided into two sections: Recognition of Famous Artists and Recognition of Classmates "Art. Recognition of Famous Artists For the task in which art students were asked which famous artist painted each painting, the mean correct ratio was 0.78 (SD = 0.12). The correct ratio, which would have been achieved on the basis of random guesses, was 0.20. This difference is statistically significant, t (9) = 15.3, p <.0001, r (effect size) = 0.98. Thus, art students could randomly distinguish which famous artists had not seen works of art before. Recognition of artworks by classmates The students themselves achieved a similar result with artworks. The correct mean ratio was 0.74 (SD = 0.29). The proportionality that would have been achieved on the basis of random guesses is.11. This difference is significant, t (9) = 6.8, p < 0.0001, r = 0.92.

sections.heading: Notion of a Writer’s ‘Voice’
sections.text: This study tested the hypothesis that people who are very familiar with the work of a particular writer will recognize other works by that writer that they have not previously encountered.

sections.heading: Method
sections.text: The research was conducted with seven students from the University of British Columbia, who were very familiar with five well-known authors, and with other authors. Materials and Procedures The analogous approach to the students described above was used for creative writing. Prior to the study, they were asked to write a passage about a kitchen and a poem over a month of the year. They were explicitly asked not to include any content in their writing (e.g., no mention of the surfing they like); they were constituted in their two parts. At the beginning of the study, they were confronted with three known passages of text.

sections.heading: Results
sections.text: Results are divided into two sections: Recognition of Famous Writers and Recognition of Classmates. Recognition of Famous Writers For creative writing students exposed to text passages by famous authors, the mean correct ratio was 0.34 (SD = 0.28). The correct ratio, which would have been achieved on the basis of random guesses, is 0.10. This difference is significant, t (7) = 7.0, p < 0.0001, r = 0.94. Thus, creative writing students correctly identified text passages by famous authors they had not previously known. Recognition of classmates "writing A similar but less pronounced result was obtained with text passages written by the students themselves. The mean correct ratio was 0.27 (SD = 0.16). The correct ratio, which would have been achieved on the basis of random guesses, is amounted.14. This difference is significant, written by the students themselves. The average correct ratio was 0.27 (SD = 0.16).

sections.heading: Method
sections.text: Participants The same seven students from the University of British Columbia who participated in Study 2 also participated in Study 3. They were very familiar with each other's writing but not familiar with each other's art. Materials Each student brought a piece of covert art to the professor's office. They were asked to hide their signature and other identifying features. Prior to the study, the paintings were examined to ensure that signatures and other identifying features had been hidden. Procedures Students were shown unsigned artwork made by classmates. They were given a questionnaire and asked to guess which classmate made which artwork. As described above, they were asked with each answer to indicate on a scale of 1-3 how certain they were that they had not yet seen the work.

sections.heading: Results
sections.text: The mean correct ratio was.39 (SD =.27). The correct ratio that would have been achieved on the basis of random guesses is.17. This difference is significant, t (6) = 2.2, p < 0.03, r =.67. Thus, students of creative writing could see by chance which of their classmates created a particular work in a field other than writing, especially art.
